moves.1. c4 Nf6: I haven't really decided what to play against the english opening, so I chose an Indian defence setup. (I think it's called the English Indian)
moves.8. Bg2 a6: Denying his knight more squares, which means his other knight won't be too hopeful
moves.10. cxd5 exd5 11. d3 Bf5: The pawn on d3 can't move
moves.12. e4: His bishop won't thank him for this move
moves.12... d4: Retreating the bishop doesn't look great, so I look for complications
moves.13. Na4: I guess now I'm in trouble
moves.13... b5: I can't save the c5 pawn, so I just hope that Ra-c1 will give me counterplay.
moves.14. Nxc5 Bg4 15. f3 Bd7: The bishop went to g4 first so he'd be forced to block in his bishop
moves.16. b4 Bb6: I'm down a pawn, but I think I have good chances
moves.17. Bb2 a5 18. Nxd4 Ne5: Exchanging knigts would probably be good for white. Now I'm 2 pawns down, I have to keep pieces on the board if I want to win
moves.19. Nxb5 Bxb5 20. Bxe5 Bxd3: Did he miss that his knight was pinned? Now I'm only 2 pawns down again \O/
moves.21. Bxf6 Bxc2 22. Bxd8 Raxd8 23. Kh1 Bxc: I'm probably worse here, but I play for complications
moves.26... g5 27. h3 h5 28. Bf3 Rc3 29. Kg2 h: I saw that the bishop could be pinned - and then I realised it really wasn't a pin at all!
moves.37. Rc1 Bf5+: Honestly, I'm pretty lucky he didn't see it.
moves.41. h5 Rc3 42. h6+ Kh7 43. Kf6 Rc5: Maybe just pushing the passed pawn is better, but Bf5+ worried me
moves.44. Bf5+ Rxf5+ 45. Kxf5: I was pretty pleased with the exchange sac - and then I realised that all the variations led to white winning! Keeping my rook might've been better
moves.45... a4 46. h4: Wasting time. I thought Kc3xc2 should win, but after 46. Kc3 a3 47. Kxc2 a7 48. g6+ Kxh6 49. g2 a1=Q g8=Q black can probably hold the draw. (edge-pawns are drawish anyway, and queen engames as well, so this endgame doubly so). a4 may still draw, but it gives me chances I don't really deserve
moves.47... a2 48. g6+ fxg6+ 49. hxg6+ Kxh6:
The point is that white needed to get to f6 to advance his pawn, where I just queen with check. (I even thought the final position was drawn, and was shocked when he resigned)

So, in summary: the player who's worse off should probably look to complicate things, seeing as he doesn't have much to lose. But he could probably do better off by making sure he doesn't end up with a bad position in the first place. (I think what I did was look for complications in a balanced position, which isn't quite right, but at least I got my worse position in the end. Complications will do that!)
